tossups.question: After drowning one of this man’s subordinates, terrified rebels kept a sleepless 3-day watch, as a mis-reading of Christian mythology led them to fear the corpse would reanimate into a violent, godlike zombie. When Diego Salcedo remained dead, Agueybana II instead led a revolt against this man, who had been dispatched by governor Nicolas de Ovando. This man’s major venture was hatched to thwart claims by Christopher Colombus’s son Diego, and followed his pacification of the (*) Taíno Uprising of 1511. This man was killed by Calusa natives during a series of voyages that led to the discovery of the Gulf Stream. Rumors about the aphrodisiac Bahamian Love Vine may have led to this man's landing to the south of what would become St. Augustine. For 10 points, name this Spanish conquistador, a governor of Puerto Rico who probably wasn't looking for the Fountain of Youth when he reached Florida.
tossups.answer: Juan Ponce de León <History - Other/World>

tossups.question: Although the time taken for this process is much longer than the repetition time of FLASH, signal is permitted to accumulate over time via low-flip angle pulses. “Weighting images” towards a specific measure of this phenomenon, which can be accomplished by controlling TR and TE values, allows discrimination between tissues with high water and high fat content. When (*) autocorrelation time for molecular tumbling motion is known, BPP theory allows this phenomenon to be calculated for a pure substance. It accounts for a term in a time-evolution equation equal to the difference between magnetization vector and the external field, all over a time constant. NOESY [“nosy”] measures coupling of a form of this phenomenon that occurs between spatially close atoms. The Bloch equations can compute the magnetization vector of a sample in this process as a function of time. The time taken for this process to randomize spin directions in a sample is denoted T2. For 10 points, name this equilibration process of a sample’s magnetization in NMR.
tossups.answer: spin relaxation [accept spin-spin relaxation or spin-lattice relaxation] <Science - Chemistry>

tossups.question: A recently-deceased ophthalmologist best known for activism about this activity is the subject of a lawsuit brought by Hassan Ahmad, who wants the University of Michigan to unseal his private papers. The Social Contract Press, which mainly publishes articles about this activity, was founded by that man, John Tanton, whose organization runs the cringeworthy “Hold Their Feet to the Fire” event to lobby policymakers about this activity, and is known as FAIR. The economics of this activity is studied by Giovanni Peri and George (*) Borjas. Changes in the attitudes of those who engage in this activity will facilitate the rise of“Davos Men” according to the final book by Samuel Huntington, whose book Who Are We? argues that those who engage in this activity are no longer compelled to embrace distinctly Anglo-Protestant values. The so-called “Gang of 8” pushed a Senate bill about this activity, which was the subject of the Hart–Celler Act. For 10 points, identify this activity that has historically occurred through sites like Castle Garden and Angel Island.
tossups.answer: immigration [or immigrants; accept any specific kind of immigration; prompt on gaining citizenship with “after doing what action?”; prompt on discrimination or similar answers with “against which group?”] <Modern World>

tossups.question: Note to moderator: This answerline is a bit complicated—maybe check it over before starting. Amy Levy wrote an essay praising the “wonderful accessibility” of this location, as well as a short story about a “recent telepathic occurrence” in it. A Louis MacNeice poem named for this place describes how “stooping haunted” people go “up and down” its alleys to “Deaden the drumming of the demon in their ears.” Several chapters in New Grub Street describe Marian Yule’s miserable toil in this location, which Jasper Milvain calls “the valley of the shadow of (*) books.” It’s compared to a “huge bald forehead” in the second section of A Room of One’s Own, in which the narrator discovers the anger of male professors analyzing women upon visiting this room. In a story by Max Beerbohm, Enoch Soames makes a deal with the devil to appear in this room on June 3, 1997. After it opened in 1857, people like Vladimir Lenin had to apply for a ticket to study here. For 10 points, name this domed room in the center of the British Museum, which once housed its massive library.
tossups.answer: the Reading Room of the British Museum [or the library of the British Museum before mentioned; or the Reading Room of the former British Library until “library”; prompt on “British Museum” with “Where in the British Museum?” before mentioned; accept Reading Room after “British Museum” is said] <Literature - British>

tossups.question: In the last movement of a piece by a composer from this family, the first violin plays every rotation of a 10-note tone row, followed by the rotations of its transposition up a step and then its retrograde. In that string quartet by a composer from this family, the melody of the slow movement is expressed almost entirely in terms of dynamic changes on a mass of held notes. A member of this family reversed all of Fux’s rules to get a theory of “dissonant counterpoint.” A 1931 string quartet was written by (*) Ruth Crawford just before she married into this family. A member of this family wrote songs like “Dear Mr. President” for the Almanac Singers and was the founding leader of The Weavers. That member of this family founded People’s Songs with Alan Lomax and wrote the song “Where Have All the Flowers Gone?” For 10 points, give this last name of the folk singer who wrote “If I Had a Hammer.”
tossups.answer: Seeger [accept Charles Seeger, Ruth Crawford Seeger, or Pete Seeger; prompt on Crawford by asking “What’s her married name?”] <Arts - Auditory>

tossups.question: This book was written “twice simultaneously” according to a later thinker: once in a continuous stream and once in a broken chain. That later thinker claimed that this book’s style is an opposition to “satire” through “vital and optical rectification.” An appendix in this book claims that “our actions” are always good but “the rest may be either good or bad.” This book argues that we distinguish between bodies based on their motion or rest, not their substance. Deleuze called this book a “voyage in immanence” in his monograph on its author. This book contains the claim that the (*) order and connection of ideas is the same as the order and connection of things. This book’s most famous claim is preceded by showing that any substance is infinite and indivisible. This book’s fourteenth proposition is that “besides God, no substance can be granted or conceived.” For 10 points, name this book, written in “geometrical order” as the magnum opus of Baruch Spinoza.
tossups.answer: Ethics, Demonstrated in Geometrical Order [or Ethica, ordine geometrico demonstrata] <Philosophy>

tossups.question: A superficial member of this family angrily forces his wife to change into red shoes to match her red dress immediately after brushing off a relative dying of cancer in his impatience to attend a masked ball. At a party held in this family’s mansion, the narrator initially thinks the guests are wearing powdered wigs, but realizes that they have simply grown old. After moving into an apartment owned by this family, the narrator begins stalking one of its members, Oriane, on her morning walk. At the end of the novel, we learn that the (*) Prince of this family, seeking to recoup losses suffered during World War I, has married the wealthy Madame Verdurin. As a young adult, the narrator is infatuated with the Duchess of this aristocratic family, whose members include Robert de Saint-Loup and the Baron de Charlus. For 10 points, name this family whose “way” titles the third novel of Marcel Proust’s In Search of Lost Time.
tossups.answer: Guermantes family [accept, Duchesse of Guermantes, Duke of Guermantes, or Prince of Guermantes; accept The Guermantes’ Way or Le côté de Guermantes] <Literature - European>

tossups.question: In the 2013 Italian Colors case, the Supreme Court ruled that an infeasible cost of pursuing this process does not fall under the “effective vindication” rule. Because a certain law’s “savings clause” is not at odds with Section 7 of the Wagner Act, the Supreme Court ruled in 2018 that the plaintiffs of Epic Systems Corp v. Lewis had to undergo this process. In AT&T Mobility v. Concepcion, the Supreme Court found that companies that provide consumer contracts with (*) class action waivers can force consumers to participate in the individual form of this process. Most collective bargaining agreements in the U.S. make this process the final step in the grievance procedure. The non-binding form of this process is similar to mediation, and this process is resolved by a namesake tribunal determining an “award” for the claimant. For 10 points, name this process in which an independent authority decides a dispute outside of court.
tossups.answer: arbitration [accept word forms and more specific versions, such as contract arbitration and non-binding arbitration; prompt on alternative dispute resolution or ADR; do not accept “mediation”] <Social Science>

tossups.question: Description acceptable. One instance of this action was influenced by anger that its target may have supported Sepé Tiaraju, who revolted after the transfer of a group of frontier settlements. The last major example of this action was carried out to deflect blame for a riot triggered by a law that offended national masculinity by banning long capes and wide-brimmed hats. In France, this action occurred after the loss of cargo ships from Martinique ruined the fortunes of Antoine de la Valette, which allowed the crown to bankrupt the targets of this action. The Esquilache Riots led to this action in Spain. Gabriel (*) Malagrida’s relationship with Leonor of Tavora was used by the Marquis of Pombal as a pretext to launch this kind of action in Portugal. Clement XIII resisted significant pressure to pursue this effort, which Clement XIV soon gave into by issuing the brief Dominus ac Redemptor and blacklisting Lorenzo Ricci. European leaders pushed this action to weaken the target group’s cultural and social power, particularly in education. For 10 points, identify this series of eighteenth-century campaigns that ousted a religious order founded by Ignatius of Loyola.
tossups.answer: expelling the Jesuits [or expelling the Society of Jesus; accept any equivalents like persecuting or suppressing or targeting the Jesuits; prompt on descriptions of persecuting religious orders but don’t accept other specific instances of that] <History - Mediterranean+>

tossups.question: These sets can be represented by using a Markov partition to generate a finite set of symbols. Under Stephen Smale’s horseshoe map, the points in these sets that fall within the original square form a set whose horizontal and vertical components are homeomorphic to the Cantor Set. In the two-dimensional case, if these sets do not contain a fixed point, they must be periodic according to the Poincaré–Bendixson theorem. These sets are (*) “homoclinic” if they approach an equilibrium point going either forward or backward in time. A periodic solution to a differential equation forms a “closed” example of these sets. These sets can spiral into a limit cycle or other kinds of attractors. Periodic examples of these sets are dense in chaotic systems. For 10 points, name these sets traced out by a dynamical system’s evolution function given a set of initial conditions.
tossups.answer: orbits [accept trajectory or connections; prompt on flow] <Science - Other>

tossups.question: On the left-hand side of a painting by this artist, Moses holds the Ten Commandments and watches while a spear-wielding skeleton and a horned demon chase a nude man into Hell. In another painting by this artist, Cupid is attacked by bees while holding a honeycomb for Venus, who wears an ostrich-feather hat and grabs a branch of an apple tree. Carts carry old women from the left to the central rectangular pool of this artist’s The Fountain of Youth. This man’s skinny, tall nude (*) Eves are often indistinguishable from his many nude paintings of Venus. This artist’s painting and woodcut Law and Gospel was likely made in consultation with Philip Melanchthon. He signed his paintings with a winged snake emblem bestowed on him by Frederick III. For 10 points, name this court painter of Saxony who painted many portraits of Martin Luther.
tossups.answer: Lucas Cranach the Elder <Arts - Visual>

tossups.question: Description acceptable. During this specific event, one participant noted that another’s response was “entirely predictable” before expressing bemusement at the idea that “the crime is not the burglar but the discovery of the burglar.” A participant opined that he “[was] not in a courtroom” before saying “do not worry” during this event, which included a reference to an open letter written to Bertrand Russell. This event, which occurred a few hours after a decision to ignore the Bucharest, included a reference to a similar instance of deceit in which one participant broke a moratorium a year earlier with the (*) Tsar Bomba test. Blown-up photos of San Cristobal were displayed during this event, whose primary participant avowed that he was “prepared to wait for my answer until Hell freezes over” and castigated the silence of Valerian Zorin by demanding “don’t wait for the translation!” For 10 points, identify this October 1962 speech given by an Illinois politician and U.S. Ambassador before a world governing body, which exposed Soviet nuclear platforms in Cuba.
tossups.answer: Adlai Stevenson’s speech at the U.N. during the Cuban Missile Crisis [accept any answer mentioning both Stevenson and the United Nations or Stevenson and the Cuban Missile Crisis; accept answers about Stevenson and Valerian Zorin before mentioned; prompt on answers that don’t mention Stevenson by asking “Who gave the speech?”] <History - American>

tossups.question: After a period named for this phenomenon, laypeople give monks new robes in the festival of Kathina. That period named for this phenomenon concludes with a day of repentance called Pavarana. Tal is omitted when reciting a prayer concerning this phenomenon, which was invoked with “bells” by priests who imitated the sounds of ducks and geese while swimming in a lake. In Theravada traditions, a three-month, Lent-like “retreat” named for this phenomenon is called vassa. This phenomenon is invoked with a prayer beginning “masheev ha’rua’ch” starting on (*) Shemini Atzeret. Geshem invokes this phenomenon, four sub-deities of which were said to hold jugs on a sacred mountain that was represented by one half of the Templo Mayor. The Aztec god of this phenomenon married the jade-skirted goddess Chal·chiuht·licue. For 10 points, name this phenomenon controlled by Chac and Tlaloc.
tossups.answer: rain [accept storms; prompt on answers like weather or precipitation; prompt on agriculture; prompt on water; accept mist or fog, but do not accept or prompt on “dew”] <Religion>

tossups.question: Actor George Handel Hill earned this nickname because of his monologues depicting this type of character on the London stage. The first chapter of Constance Rourke’s study American Humor analyzes this type of character, and describes how the letters of Major Jack Downing turned this type of character into a “mythical oracle.” Thomas Chandler Haliburton invented one of the most famous of these characters, the clockmaker Sam Slick. These characters were typically depicted as both (*) shrewd, calculating peddlers and awkward, naïve rustics. They usually spoke in a nasal twang and used words like “splendiferous,” as exemplified by Asa Trenchard in Our American Cousin. These characters were often called “Brother Jonathan,” a nickname popularized by one of them called Jonathan in Royall Tyler’s play The Contrast. For 10 points, name this stock character, an early comic personification of America based on the stereotypical inhabitants of New England.
tossups.answer: Yankees [or stage Yankees; or Yankee peddlers; or Yankee farmers; accept Brother Jonathan before mentioned] <Literature - American>

tossups.question: This thinker recounted his first engagement with mortality, in which he burned one of his hairs in a fire as a child, in the autobiography The Heart of Matter. This man worked with Franz Wiedenreich during a lengthy stint abroad that saw him pen A Mass on the World in the Ordos Desert. That stay in Asia was prompted by his work Fall, Redemption, and Geocentry, which controversially critiqued Original Sin. Julian Huxley wrote the preface to this man’s most famous book, which argued that an increasing complexity and interchange of ideas would create a new (*) field of consciousness enveloping the earth, an idea developed with Vladimir Vernadsky and Eduard LeRoy that this man called the “noosphere.” This man identified the Logos of Christ with an ur-consciousness toward driving humanity was being driven by evolution in the book The Phenomenon of Man. For 10 points, name this French Jesuit philosopher, who theorized the Omega Point and co-discovered Peking Man.
tossups.answer: Pierre Teilhard [teh-YAHR] de Chardin [shar-DAAN] <Mythology and Other>

tossups.question: The cephalic vein is a superficial vein overlaying this bone, and Smith’s and Colles’ fractures occur in its distal aspect. De Quervain teno·synovitis involves a non-inflammatory thickening of the first extensor compartment’s sheath, which overlays this bone. An associated nerve that shares this bone’s name arises from the posterior cord and can be compressed in the supinator canal, leading to its namesake “tunnel syndrome.” Preschool-age children often experience subluxation of this bone’s head due to slight overgrowth of the (*) annular ligament, which is often attributed to “nursemaids” pulling on the child’s arm. The antero·lateral branch of the deep brachial artery becomes this bone’s deep artery once it crosses the elbow. This bone abuts the scaphoid and lunate carpal bones and articulates with the capitulum of the humerus. For 10 points, name this bone that’s bound to the ulna by an inter·osseus membrane.
tossups.answer: radius [accept radial tunnel syndrome] <Science - Biology>

tossups.question: This substance is the last title word of a novel featuring an iridologist known as the Sweet Sunday Man, who persuades the protagonist to steal one of Gertrude Stein’s manuscripts. An unnamed “man on the bridge” is hinted to be Ho Chi Minh in a novel titled for this substance that centers on the gay Vietnamese cook Bình. The brothers Mizban and Hajem teach workers how to swim in another novel partly named for this title substance of Monique Truong’s first novel. The Atoum patriarch (*) Miteb appears in a novel titled for this substance that was the first published translation of Peter Theroux. In another novel titled for this substance, the jealous husband Harge threatens to expose the relationship between Carol Aird and Therese Belivet. This substance is used to describe oil-rich Arabian cities in the title of a novel by Saudi author Abdul Rahman Munif. For 10 points, name this title substance of a “lesbian novel” named for its “price,” written by Patricia Highsmith
tossups.answer: salt [accept The Book of Salt; accept Cities of Salt; accept The Price of Salt; do not accept or prompt on putative synonyms] <Literature - Other/World>

tossups.question: In a late work by this choreographer, motion-capture animations are projected onto a transparent curtain in front of the dancers. This choreographer’s created late works like CRWDSPCR [“crowd spacer”] using the programs LifeForms and DanceForms. As a dancer, this choreographer premiered the role of the Preacher in Appalachian Spring. In collaboration with Christian Wolff, this choreographer began to rehearse the dancers without the (*) music, while telling the composer nothing about the dance. Found objects and clothing were used to costume this choreographer’s dance Story by Robert Rauschenberg, his colleague at Black Mountain College. This man designed Sixteen Dances for Soloist and Company of Three using coin flips and the I Ching. For 10 points, name this choreographer and longtime partner of John Cage.
tossups.answer: Merce Cunningham [or Mercier Philip Cunningham] (The first work is BIPED.) <Arts - Audiovisual, Other>

tossups.question: In MOSFETs, when the square root of current is plotted against gate voltage in the saturated current regime, this quantity is proportional to the square of the slope of the resulting line. K-dot-p perturbation theory allows computation of an effective mass term, which can be multiplied by scattering time and charge to yield this quantity. Modeling of acoustic phonon interaction predicts that this quantity decays as temperature-to-the negative three-halves, whereas interaction with optical phonons only causes a “T-to-the negative one-half” decay. This quantity is equal to (*) “electric charge times diffusion constant over k T” in the Einstein relation, and its value for holes in undoped crystalline silicon at room temperature is only 32% of its value for electrons. For 10 points, name this quantity formally defined as the drift velocity of charge carriers divided by the electric field strength.
tossups.answer: mobility [do not prompt on “resistivity” or “conductivity”] <Science - Physics>

tossups.question: The primary target of this event had a difficult childhood during which his father had German police kidnap him back from his mother Natalie, who had absconded with him to Wiesbaden [VEEZ-bah-dun]. This event brought to power a group that had been arrested after the Timok Rebellion but was released when the target of this action inherited the throne at just 13. One of the men killed during this event was a senior military official who had reportedly failed the officers’ exam numerous times, but was promoted anyway thanks to his friendship with King (*) Milan. This action, which led to the crowning of Peter the Liberator, was partly inspired by one target’s rumored sterility. The targets of this action were discovered hiding in a wardrobe, after which they were mutilated and thrown out a window onto a pile of manure. This event was organized by a man known as Apis, the leader of the Black Hand, and it ended the House of Obrenovic. For 10 points, name this 1903 event in which King Alexander and Queen Draga were killed in the Royal Palace in Belgrade during the namesake month in springtime.
tossups.answer: May Coup [or Majski prevrat; accept the assassination of Alexander of Serbia and Draga or similar answers before mentioned] <History - European>   Chicago Open 2019: What If We Kissed 😳 in the Non-Western Art Distribution 😳  Edited by Chris Ray, Jacob Reed, Alston Boyd, Will Holub-Moorman, Jonathan Magin, and Sriram Pendyala, with contributions by Wonyoung Jang and Michael Kearney.  Packet by the Editors (Finals 1)  Bonuses

bonuses.leadin: A sonnet about a woman with this role ends “But O as to embrace me she enclin’d / I wak’d, she fled, and day brought back my night.” For 10 points each:
answer: John Milton’s wives [prompt on wives by asking “The wife of what person?”]

The Tenure of Kings and Magistrates Proving, That it is Lawfull, and hath been held so through all Ages, for any who have the Power, to call to account a Tyrant, or wicked KING, and after due conviction, to depose and put him to death; if the ordinary MAGISTRATE have neglected or deny’d to doe it. And that they, who of late, so much blame Deposing, are the Men that did it themselves <Literature - British>
parts: Name this role held at different times by three women, including Katharine Woodcock, that sonnet’s “late espoused saint.” An author’s failed relationship with the first woman with this role, Mary Powell, likely inspired tracts like The Judgment of Martin Bucer.
Milton’s unhappy marriage to Mary Powell may have led him to write four tracts advocating this practice, including Tetrachordon and a tract about its “doctrine and discipline.”
After the restoration, Milton was nearly executed for writing this political pamphlet, which justified the regicide of Charles I by arguing that subjects have the right to kill an oppressive tyrant.

bonuses.leadin: This book claims that its subject's conception of “limit” comes from Schopenhauer. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this book, whose last chapter, titled “Mysticism and Solipsism,” attempts to explain how its subject can claim that solipsism is both true and unsayable.
That Introduction was written by this philosopher, who also translated Wittgenstein’s Philosophical Investigations. She introduced the idea of “acting under a description” in the monograph Intention.

Anscombe began a paper titled for these things with the suggestion that one could avoid paying a grocer by invoking Hume’s guillotine. Searle used “having a bit of green paper with a face” as an example of these things.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about multiterminal circuit elements, for 10 points each.
parts: This is an ideal two-port circuit element that has perfectly antisymmetric impedance and admittance matrices. The current on the first port is proportional to the voltage on the second, and the current on the second is proportional to the negative voltage on the first.

These devices take as input the difference between two voltages and output a voltage equal to that difference multiplied by some fixed amount. One of the “golden rules” for these devices states that in a closed loop circuit the inputs are ideal voltmeters, whereas the output is an ideal current source.
For a closed-loop op-amp with negative feedback, this value limits to one over the feedback. It’s defined as the closed-loop output voltage over the input voltage.

bonuses.leadin: Jeanne de Clisson became well-known for this action after the murder of her husband in the War of Breton Succession. For 10 points each:
answer: piracy [or privateering; accept descriptive answers; prompt on mercenary work; prompt on sailing or other nautical answers]
parts: Identify this primary activity of men like Eustace the Monk. In the lands of Rus, the Ushkuyniks were best known for this activity.

Eustace the Monk was such a good pirate that he actually had to be a negotiating party in the Treaty of Lambeth, which Louis VIII the Lion signed with regent William Marshal because this English king had just died. This king sucked so much that he actually got feudal nobility to support legal rights, forcing the Magna Carta.

Eustace the Monk was defeated at the Battle of Sandwich by Philip d’Aubigny, who was commanding a fleet supplied by this group. This group, which included Hastings and New Romney, became a pseudo-polity responsible for maintaining English ships, for which almost all of their nobility was granted the status of Baron.

bonuses.leadin: XIST, a major effector of lyonization, is a gene coding for one of these. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these largely nuclear-localizing RNAs that have high developmental stage specificity and are thought to regulate chromatin structure and gene transcription. There are tens of thousands of these RNAs, with very few having known functions.
This lncRNA has been shown to regulate the expression of metastasis-associated genes like the pro-metastatic transcriptional regulator YAP65 in both lung adenocarcinoma and breast cancer.
LncRNAs have emerged as important regulators of ribosomal RNA production in this cellular substructure. LncRNAs capture and detain proteins like RelA, vHL, and TERT in this cellular substructure.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about post-Roman civilizations who based their origin myths on Troy, for 10 points each.
answer: Prose Edda [or Younger Edda; or Snorri's Edda; or Snorra Edda]
parts: The euhemerized prologue to this work presents a genealogy claiming that Priam was the grandfather of Thor. This work by Snorri Sturluson is best known for its next section, the Gylfaginning.

Similarly to the Prose Edda, the chronicle attributed to this author claimed that Priam was the first king of the Franks. This author’s chronicle, which narrates the history of the world up to 642 AD, is a major primary source for the history of the Merovingian Dynasty along with the work of Gregory of Tours.

According to Geoffrey of Monmouth’s Historia Regum Britanniae, this grandson of Ascanius became the first king of Britain after leading a group of Trojans to the country and founding Troia Nova on the River Thames.

bonuses.leadin: This book argues that, “for the most part,” American literature “has taken as its concern the architecture of a new white man.” For 10 points each:
answer: Playing in the Dark: Whiteness and the Literary Imagination
The Narrative of Arthur Gordon Pym of Nantucket <Literature - American>
parts: Name this 1992 book, which analyzes how white authors have used the “Africanist presence” of black characters to “imaginatively act out the forbidden in American culture.”
The third essay in Toni Morrison’s Playing in the Dark analyzes how Harry Morgan compares sex with a black woman to “nurse shark” in this author’s novel To Have and Have Not.

Another essay in Playing in the Dark focuses on the ending of this book, in which a giant, shrouded figure with skin “the perfect whiteness of the snow” appears after the death of Nu-Nu. Its concluding note explains that the natives of Tsalal were terrified by whiteness.

bonuses.leadin: Most Shi’a Muslims attribute this quality to imams on the basis of the Verse of Purification. For 10 points each:
answer: Ahl al-Bayt [accept People of the House; accept Ahl al-Kisa’ or People of the Cloak or People of the Mantle; prompt on answers like Muhammad’s family by asking “What’s the specific term?”]
Battle of the Trench [or Ghazwat al-Khandaq] <Religion>
parts: Name this status of infallibility that some Muslims attribute to prophets and angels.
The Verse of Purification more directly applies to this group, who, along with the Quran, are one of the “Two Weighty Things.” This group was even closer to Muhammad than the sahabah.
The Verse of Purification is taken from a sura that also decries the “confederates” at this battle, in which the early Muslims held off a siege of Medina using the namesake defensive structure.

bonuses.leadin: John Marshall unusually did not write the opinion for this case, having recused himself over a conflict of interest. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this case stemming from a dispute over land in Northern Neck granted to the Loyalist plaintiff by Lord Fairfax and confiscated during the Revolutionary War.

Martin v. Hunter’s Lessee established Supreme Court jurisdiction over state courts on issues of federal law, thus reversing a finding by this state’s supreme court. The Loving case emerged from this state.

The opinion in Martin v. Hunter’s Lessee was instead written by this justice, who also wrote the majority opinions for Prigg v. Pennsylvania. This man was preparing a majority decision for Charles River Bridge Co. when John Marshall died, forcing this man to then deliver the first dissent of the Taney court.

bonuses.leadin: This photographer first came to prominence for her 1996 book Down in the Garden, which uses props like plastic buckets and flowerpots. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Australian photographer now based in New Zealand, who’s best-known for her whimsical costumed photos of infants.

In 2017, this publisher released a coffee-table book of Geddes’s work titled Small World. Like Prestel and Phaidon, this German publisher almost exclusively releases art books, including its series “Basic Art” and “SUMO.”

A 2014 entry in Taschen’s SUMO series features this woman’s nude photos of Keith Haring and Whoopi Goldberg. This woman’s 1980 photo of Yoko Ono and John Lennon was taken just before his assassination.

bonuses.leadin: This European Space Agency observatory has produced the most precise astrometric database to date. For 10 points each:
answer: Type Ia supernovae [prompt on partial answer]
parts: Name this observatory currently at the Earth-Sun L2 point, which can measure the position, parallax, and proper motion of more than a billion stars to an accuracy of 20 micro-arcseconds.

Gaia has recorded numerous hypervelocity white dwarves in the Milky Way, providing evidence for the D6 hypothesis concerning the cause of these stellar events. “High-Z” examples of these events were the initial evidence for the accelerating expansion of the universe, and they require the accretion of matter by a white dwarf.

Gaia has provided more accurate values for these parameters, which are defined as the solar system’s rotational velocity and radius from the galactic center. These parameters both have units of kilometers per second per kiloparsec.

bonuses.leadin: A possibly-sensationalized account relates how the sides in this war competed to see who could carry out the most gruesome executions from atop a stone “New Bridge” that spanned a massive chasm. For 10 points each:
answer: Spanish Civil War [or Guerra Civil Española]
Trajan [or Marcus Ulpius Traianus; accept Trajan’s Column]

Fitna of al-Andalus [or Andalusian Succession war; or Succession War of the Cordoba Caliphate; prompt on answers involving civil war and either al-Andalus or Cordoba; do not accept anything about the Reconquista or Christians fighting Muslims] <History - Mediterranean+>
parts: Name this conflict, which may have become economically unwinnable for the losers after they were cut off by the Gipuzkoa Campaign, which helped the victors win the War in the North.

As its name suggests, the Puente Nuevo is not nearly as old as the Alcantara Bridge, a Roman structure built by this successor of Nerva. This man’s victory in the Dacian Wars is commemorated on a namesake monument.

The Puente Nuevo allows access to Ronda, a city that became a key strategic center during this conflict, which led to the rise of the Hammudids. It was triggered by the assassination of Abd al-Rahman Sanchuelo, the son of Almanzor.

bonuses.leadin: This author became the editor of a magazine called The Animal World, but was fired for writing articles about imaginary animals. For 10 points each:
answer: brothels [or bordellos; or bawdyhouses; or cathouses; or clear equivalents that mean “a house of prostitution”] <Literature - European>
parts: Name this notorious prankster who jokingly founded the Party of Modest Progress Within the Bounds of the Law. Cecil Parrott translated this author’s best-known book into English, years after it was popularized throughout Europe by Grete Reiner’s German translation.
Hašek is best known for writing about this amiable, innocent Czech soldier, who is sent closer and closer to the front of World War I after being drafted into the Austrian army.

In a comic scene from The Good Soldier Švejk, Lieutenant Dub is embarrassingly found drunk in one of these places. The narrator of Notes from Underground follows Simonov to one of these places, where he meets and belittles a woman named Liza.

bonuses.leadin: A fourth-century poet with this surname wrote a square-shaped 240-character poem that can be read in over 3,000 different ways, which is nicknamed her “star gauge” or astrolabe. For 10 points each:
answer: Sū [soo] (The poets are Sū Shì/Sū Dōngpō and Sū Hùi.)
Battle of Red Cliffs [or Chìbì zhī zhàn]
autumn [or qiū [chyoh]; accept autumn day or other clear subsets and equivalents] <Literature - Other/World>
parts: Give this surname shared by a Sòng dynasty poet who was censored after the Crow Terrace Trial. That poet with this surname wrote many cí [tsuh] lyrics, including the most famous text for the shǔidiào [shway-DYOW], or “river” tune.

Sū Shì’s best-known works are probably a pair of fù, or “poetic essays,” titled for this site. In a Luó Guànzhōng novel, a battle at this site is decided when Zhūgě Liàng magically calls forth winds to send off his fire ships.

The Crow Terrace Trial centered on subversive allusions to a Dù Fǔ poem titled for this period of time in Kuí Prefecture. Dù Fǔ wrote a highly intricate set of eight poems titled for “stirrings” of this time period.

bonuses.leadin: This location was described Gilles Perrault’s Our Friend the King and Tahar Ben Jalloun’s bracing novel, This Blinding Absence of Light. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this secret prison in the Atlas Mountains, considered by many as the quintessential symbol of repression by Morocco’s regime.

This other political prison, which functioned both before and after the 1979 Iranian revolution, includes a wing nicknamed the “university” because of the number of students and intellectuals held there.
A school at Tuol Sleng was converted to the infamous S-21 prison and death camp by this regime, which came to power in Cambodia under Pol Pot.

bonuses.leadin: This composer used astoundingly wide ranges in the songs collected as Symphonia armoniae celestium revelationum. For 10 points each:
answer: trouvères [do not accept or prompt on “troubadours”] <Arts - Auditory>
parts: Name this medieval German abbess who also wrote the musical play Ordo virtutum.

Hildegard’s music is now best-known through the recordings of this ensemble once led by Barbara Thornton and Benjamin Bagby. They’ve also released acclaimed recordings of works by Philip the Chancellor and Philippe de Vitry.

Sequentia also released a pioneering set of music by these northern French composers, who included Jehannot de Lescurel and Adam de la Halle. Unlike composers from the south, they wrote in a precursor to modern French.

bonuses.leadin: This theory models Gibbs free energies as parabolic functions of the reaction coordinate. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this theory developed by a Caltech physical chemist that predicts, in certain regimes, that activation energy increases as reactions become more exergonic. It models reactions partially as electrostatic interactions between two conducting spheres submerged in a dielectric solvent.

Supposing outer-sphere contributions dominate, the Gibbs free energy of activation for a self-exchange reaction is exactly equal to one-quarter of this value. This value is the electrostatic energy of a configuration where solvent dipoles are aligned with the oxidized reactant, rather than the reduced product.

The inner-sphere contribution to the activation energy in Marcus theory is influenced by this type of molecular motion, which is slow compared to electronic transitions. These modes of molecular motion are excited by infrared light.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the modern world, as observed by cultural critic Hanif Abdurraqib, for 10 points each.
answer: University of Texas at Austin [or UT-Austin]
parts: Abdurraqib’s 2019 book Go Ahead in the Rain is a best-selling study of this musical group. This group's album People’s Instinctive Travels and the Paths of Rhythm was the first to earn a perfect five-mic rating from The Source.

Go Ahead in the Rain is part of the American Music Project, an effort edited by rock critic Jessica Harper and published through this university’s press. This is the only school in its state that has partial exemption to a house bill requiring public universities to admit any student graduating in the top 10% of their high school class.

Abdurraqib found the Echo Hotel poetry collective with Eve Ewing, who writes heavily on race relations in this city, including its 1919 Race Riot and the demise of public schools in its Bronzeville district.

bonuses.leadin: The original version of this test included only three questions, one of which asked, “If it takes 5 machines 5 minutes to make 5 widgets, how long would it take 100 machines to make 100 widgets?” For 10 points each:
answer: Nudge: Improving Decisions about Health, Wealth, and Happiness <Social Science>
parts: Name this widely-used test developed in 2005 by Shane Frederick, which purports to measure people’s “ability or disposition to resist reporting the response that first comes to mind.”

The CRT draws upon a framework developed by Keith Stanovich and Richard West that divides cognitive processing into a type executed quickly with little deliberation and a type that’s slower and more reflective. Give the names for both types of processing.

This 2008 manifesto for libertarian paternalism authored by Cass Sunstein and Richard Thaler reprints the CRT in full as evidence that the world should be structured to allow people to rely on their “Automatic System.”

bonuses.leadin: The tiled floor of this space is decorated with eight-pointed stars arranged in the shape of a Greek Cross. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this sacred space, in which a Romanesque nave is decorated with muqarnas, while the apse has a giant mosaic of Christ Pantokrator.
The Cappella Palatina is a masterpiece of the Arab–Byzantine–Norman style that flourished on this island in the eleventh through thirteenth centuries.

The muqarnas of the Cappella Palatina are decorated in this oldest style of Arabic calligraphy, which preceded the cursive style of naskh. Most pseudo-Arabic decorations in medieval Europe were imitations of this script.
